We're in Vegas this week for our global Sales Kick-Off.

The energy in the room is incredible.

Teams from EMEA, North America, APAC, and partners are all here with one focus: how do we take what worked in 2025 and scale it properly?

This year's theme is Next Level. Because we had a strong year, but strong isn't the same as scalable. So the sessions we‚Äôre attending this week are all about execution. 

What does better look like? How do we raise the bar internally to build stronger relationships internally and externally? How do we react and build faster? How do we sharpen the way we engage with our customers?

These few days create the alignment that makes everything else possible.

When you're running distributed teams, it's too easy for priorities to drift or for regions to start solving the same problems differently. Getting everyone together resets that. 

It reminds us we're building something bigger than any one market can deliver alone.

It's the same principle we talk about with customers evaluating workforce systems ‚Äî you can't scale well when your foundation is fragmented.

The conversations happening here aren't just about this quarter. They're about building the kind of momentum that compounds over time.

That's what matters.

I‚Äôm incredibly grateful to be working with this team.

Let‚Äôs take this to the Next Level!

If I were buying an HCM platform for the first time today, I'd spend less time on feature comparisons, and more time on lived reality.

Here are the questions I‚Äôd ask:

1. How often will this data be trusted without verification?¬†
2. Who owns issues when HR, Finance, and IT priorities collide?¬†
3. What happens when something changes at scale?

Early in buying processes, it's easy to focus on what's visible: dashboards, roadmaps, promises.

What matters later is what's invisible.

How many handoffs exist behind the scenes, how exceptions are handled, and whether leaders can rely on one version of the truth (or still reconciling three different reports).

I'd also push harder on understanding change, not just capability.

‚Üí How long before teams feel confident? 
‚Üí What does adoption actually look like six months in? 
‚Üí Where have others underestimated the effort?

The goal when investing in a new HCM platform isn‚Äôt to avoid complexity. 
It's to avoid unnecessary complexity.

This is why Dayforce is built as a single, unified platform on one database.

When there's one source of truth, trust doesn't require verification. 

When HR, Finance, and IT are working from the same foundation, ownership of issues becomes clearer. 

When exceptions are handled within one system instead of across six, they don't escalate the same way.

The right questions early on save months later. 
But the right foundation answers most of them before they become problems.

If you‚Äôre evaluating an HCM platform for the first time (or if your current platform is complicating your priorities), let me know. 

We can run through these questions together.

Before we talked about execution, we ran through Vegas solving problems as a team.

Sometimes alignment happens outside the conference room.

Ahead of officially starting Dayforce‚Äôs SKO in Vegas, we spent the day on personal development and wrapped it with a team competition ‚Äî an¬†EMEA team scavenger hunt on Fremont Street.

Different challenge, different energy, but exactly what the team needed.¬†
The session this morning was everything I hoped it would be.

The energy was sharp, the conversations were honest, and the alignment on where we're pushing this year is clear.

When you bring teams together like this, you're reminded why it matters. Not just for the strategy sessions, but for the moments in between. The scavenger hunt probably did more for team cohesion than any slide deck could.

We're deep into the full kickoff with the broader organisation for the rest of the week.

Ready to see what this team builds in 2026!

When leaders say they need "better workforce visibility," they rarely mean dashboards.

The problems are usually far more important: 

They mean: "I'm making workforce decisions with data that's already two weeks old".
They mean: "I can't see problems until they've already cost us money"
They mean: "By the time I know we're overstaffed in one region and understaffed in another, the quarter's already halfway done".

Visibility isn't about having more reports. It's about having information early enough to actually do something with it.

The gap between "what happened last month" and "what's happening right now" is where most workforce problems either get solved or get expensive.

Can you see labour costs tracking over budget in real time, or do you find out at month-end? Can you spot scheduling gaps before shifts go unfilled? Can you identify which sites are burning through overtime before it becomes a pattern?

This is why Dayforce is built for real-time workforce insights, not lagging reports.

When someone clocks in, labour cost updates immediately. When a schedule changes, visibility across the organisation updates instantly. When performance trends shift, leaders see it while there's still time to respond.

Better visibility isn't simply about seeing more data. It's about seeing the right data early enough to make better decisions.

Everyone says they want "one source of truth" until you ask them a simple question:

"When headcount changed last quarter, how long did it take for payroll, finance, and operations to align on the actual number?"

At scale ‚Äî think 10,000+ employees across regions ‚Äî that question exposes everything.

If the answer involves phrases like "we‚Äôll have to reconcile the numbers" or "depends which system you're looking at," you don't have one source of truth. You have multiple versions of truth that someone is manually aligning every month.

The cost of that isn't just time. It's confidence.

When your CFO is making workforce investment decisions and your VP of HR is reporting different headcount to the board, trust erodes fast. When operations can't get accurate labour cost per site without pulling three reports and building a spreadsheet, planning slows down.

"One source of truth" isn't a nice-to-have or a feature. It's an architecture neccesity.

This is why Dayforce is built on a single database, not modules stitched together on different datasets and linked with manual workarounds.

When payroll processes, finance sees it immediately. When someone's hired in one region, global reporting updates in real time. When compensation changes, it flows through to forecasting without manual uploads.

At enterprise scale, "one source of truth" means nobody's reconciling data that should already match.

It's validation that the way we've built Dayforce (unified, AI-enabled, designed for real workforce complexity) is exactly where the industry needs to go.

The next chapter is just beginning.

Burton Snowboards calls their old setup "HR soup‚Äù. 

It‚Äôs a really good description of the pain most of our clients feel when they come to us.

Different platforms for payroll, recruiting, benefits, time tracking, employee surveys. Systems that varied by country. No single source of truth.

The snowboard company needed everything working smoothly as they scaled, but instead, their people and culture team was drowning in administration.

Managers spent two months every year in a "spreadsheet nightmare" just managing compensation reviews. Employees logged into five or six different systems to access basic information. Payroll processing took too long, and when errors happened, finding them was painful.

They needed one unified system that could handle a complex, global workforce.¬†
That's where Dayforce came in.

Now, payroll processing takes significantly less time. Managers run global reports for workforce planning. Employees access everything from pay stubs to schedules and award letters, all in one place.

The people and culture team shifted from admin to what actually matters: employee development and growth.

When your foundation is solid, your teams can focus on the work that drives the business forward. As per their SVP of People and Culture: "We used to spend about two months a year in a spreadsheet nightmare. Dayforce has accounted for all those variables and made that much more efficient and accurate."

Sounds like a pretty simple solution to replace firefighting systems that should just work.

The AI conversation in HR has become almost useless.

Everyone's talking about it. Most of it is vague promises, fear-mongering, or vendor pitches dressed up as thought leadership.

Here's the only question that actually matters:

Where does time disappear in your organisation, and can technology give it back?

In workforce-heavy environments, I see time vanish in the same predictable patterns. 

-> Manually adjusting schedules because the system can't handle exceptions. Reconciling pay discrepancies that shouldn't exist. 

-> Hunting for information across five different systems. 

-> Managing manual workarounds that have become "just how we do things here."

This is where Dayforce‚Äôs approach of People + AI delivers real value, not by replacing jobs or reinventing how work happens, but by closing the gap between a problem and a solution.

Our AI gives users the ability to skip all the searching, the menus and the red tape to get quick answers by simply asking ‚ÄúI need my pay slips‚Äù, ‚ÄúWhen is my next shift?‚Äù or ‚ÄúI want to take leave next month.‚Äù

When leaders get clearer visibility, people get better experiences.
When teams spend less time on admin, they spend more time on work that matters.
When the basics run smoothly, trust builds without anyone needing to announce it.

The organisations I see moving fastest aren't the ones with the flashiest AI strategy decks. 

They're the ones systematically and realistically removing friction from daily work using this amazing tech.

Organisations don't usually fail at workforce transformation because they lack budget or executive support. They fail because nobody agreed on what success actually looks like.

The plan gets approved. The sponsor is named. The systems are selected. But then basic questions expose the gaps:

Who owns the outcome when something breaks? How do we decide when HR, Finance, and IT want different things? Are we willing to standardise processes, or does every department get to customise?

Those aren't planning questions. They're alignment questions, and they determine whether you can actually execute when pressure hits.

This is what we focus on with organisations considering Dayforce, long before we ever talk about features or implementation timelines.

Because here's what forces alignment: a single, unified platform built on one database with AI that makes work easier for employees, planning simpler for HR, and insights clearer for executives.

When everyone's working from the same foundation, the ambiguity that kills most implementations doesn't have room to hide. 

The teams that move quickly aren't rushing. They've done the hard work of getting clear on what good looks like. They're honest about where complexity adds value versus creating noise. 

These teams accept that successful implementations aren't about perfection, they're about being able to make decisions together when trade-offs appear, whereas the organisations that struggle may have all the resources, but they're missing that shared foundation.

If you're evaluating workforce systems this year, the most important question shouldn‚Äôt be whether you have budget or capacity for transformation. 

It's whether you're prioritising alignment between all of your stakeholders, or whether you‚Äôre happy to stick with the cost of fragmented tech and systems for another year.

If it takes your leadership team more than 60 seconds to answer basic workforce questions, you don't have a data problem.

You have a systems problem.

"What's our actual labour cost per site right now?" or "How many people are scheduled to work this weekend across operations?"

And the room goes quiet for a second, and then everybody scrambles to check their spreadsheets and make some quick calculations. 

Not because nobody knows how to find the answer, but because getting it requires pulling three different reports, reconciling two systems, and hoping the data was updated this morning.

At scale, this happens constantly.

When your workforce data lives in separate systems for HR, payroll, and scheduling, even basic questions become projects. By the time you have the answer, the conversation has moved on. Or worse, the decision gets made without it.

This is exactly what Dayforce's AI is designed to solve.

Because it's built on a single database, you can ask: "Show me overtime trends across EMEA for the last 90 days" or "Which sites are running over their labour budget this month?", and get answers in seconds, not days.

The AI doesn't need to reconcile multiple sources, because there's only one source.

That's the difference between workforce data you can actually use to make decisions and workforce data that just creates more work.

When your systems are unified, simple questions get simple answers.

When I talk to a client struggling with WFM, they don't usually say "the systems are broken."

They say "everything just feels harder."

That's when I start paying attention to where the friction is actually showing up.

Managers stretched thin dealing with exceptions instead of leading their teams. Small issues that used to get resolved quickly now escalate. People spending more time fixing problems than preventing them. Decisions slowing down because nobody fully trusts the data.

It's rarely one obvious failure. It's the accumulation of small friction points that compound over time.

The instinct when things feel heavy is to push harder. But in my experience, pressure just reveals weak foundations, it doesn't fix them.

What works is pausing to remove the friction. Simplify where things got unnecessarily complex. Stabilise what's breaking. Clarify what's become confusing.

When you do that, capacity comes back. Not because people are suddenly working more, but because they're no longer carrying unnecessary weight.

"Everything feels harder" is usually a symptom, not the actual problem.

And recognising that changes how you respond.

You can tell when a team is ready to perform at the next level.

It's not what they say in the room‚Ä¶ it's how they show up for each other.

We recently wrapped our global Sales Kick-Off in Vegas. The stage was great, and the strategy sessions were sharp. But what stood out to me most wasn't what happened on the agenda.

It was our team.

EMEA showed up differently this year. Engaged, yes, but more than that. Supportive. Celebrating each other's wins openly. Pushing each other forward instead of just showing up to listen.

Several leaders from other regions commented on it. The sense of community. The energy our team brought to the room.

That's the signal that matters to me most as a leader.

Because "next level" isn't just about hitting bigger numbers or executing faster. It's about whether your team actually believes they can do it together, and whether they want to.

We've spent the last year building something special by investing in the right people. We encouraged successful people to help newer people get there. We created space for honest conversations when things weren't working.

That work showed up big time in Vegas.

I've worked in four different organisations across three continents.

Different industries. Different markets. Different labour laws and workplace cultures. Same fundamental problems everywhere:

Teams doing solid work while fighting systems that make everything harder than it needs to be. Schedules that change without warning and wreck people's plans. Payroll errors that kill trust faster than any bad manager could. Processes designed for someone's convenience, but never theirs.

When the basics don't work (pay, time, visibility, the ability to grow) everything else becomes heavier than it should be.

Dayforce is built to solve exactly this. Not with surface fixes or band-aid/plaster integrations, but with a unified platform that large, complex, workforces can actually rely on when it matters.

This is why our EMEA expansion is so critical. These markets have high operational standards, diverse workforces, and realities that shift by the hour. 

If we can make work fundamentally smoother here, we can make it smoother anywhere.

Better doesn't always look dramatic.

Sometimes it's just the quiet relief of a schedule that makes sense. A payslip that's accurate. A system that doesn't crash mid-shift. A manager who has time to lead instead of reconciling timesheets.

That's the work that matters to the people who matter the most to your business.

My role has changed a dozen times over the years.

Sales. Training. Sales leadership. Multi-function leadership across sales, marketing, BDR, partners, and services. Regional turnarounds. Cross-continental growth.

But one principle has stayed constant through every transition.¬†
Leadership is a practice, not a position.

I don't lead the same way in every situation - context matters, culture matters, the specific challenges matter. But I try to lead in a way that gives people confidence in three core things, regardless of market or circumstance: 

1. They know what matters.

Clarity creates momentum. Uncertainty (even well-intentioned uncertainty) slows everything down and drains energy from the work that actually moves the business forward.

2. They know they can speak openly.

Honest conversations build organisations that improve and adapt. Silence, politeness, or fear just means you keep repeating the same problems under slightly different circumstances.

3. They know I'll show up consistently.

Not only when the results look good and everything's ahead of plan - especially when they don't and we need to find a different path forward.

Leading across the US, UK, and Europe taught me that style and approach need to adapt to context. But the core expectations don't change. 

People want leaders who recognise their effort, respect their time, and make decisions with real intention and thought behind them.

As Dayforce grows across EMEA, I'm more aware than ever of the responsibility that comes with scale.

People make it all possible. Make sure to treat them that way.

I learned something important about leadership when I moved from the US to Europe ten years ago - it doesn't travel on a passport.

Pace changes between markets. Expectations shift. Communication styles can be dramatically different‚Ä¶ what reads as confident in Philadelphia can come across as aggressive in London or Berlin.

But underneath all of that, people want the same fundamental things from their leaders.

Clear direction so they know where they're going and why. Room to grow without having to fight for it. A leader who shows up when things get uncomfortable, not just when results look good. A workplace where the basics like pay and schedules can actually be trusted.

What surprised me most about Europe is how much local context shapes every decision. You can't assume what works in London will work in Berlin, or that a playbook from Frankfurt will land the same way in Glasgow. 

Different labour laws, different work cultures, different expectations about everything from communication style to work-life balance.

It forces you to listen harder, adapt faster, and respect the operational realities and human stakes behind every choice you make. As Dayforce expands across EMEA, those lessons are front and centre for me every single day.

Technology matters deeply, but how people interact with it matters even more.

No two regions are identical. But the desire for work that's fair, predictable, meaningful and enables for growth‚Ä¶

That's universal.

I‚Äôve always believed that meaningful work speaks for itself.

I've spent many years growing and scaling underperforming regions, leading through mergers, and building high-engagement teams across three continents.

But recently, I realised something important. In the digital world we live in today, people can form an opinion about you long before you ever meet. 

And as Dayforce grows across the UK and Germany, the conversations we're having about People + AI, about frontline workforces, and about what actually drives results for HCM teams, deserve a wider table than the one we can physically sit around. 

So this is me building a bigger table. 

I'm using this space to share what I've learnt leading teams across the US, UK, and Europe. The practical stuff. The parts that matter when you're trying to turn around a struggling business or scale through complexity.

I‚Äôm not going to try to do the whole ‚Äúguru‚Äù thing.¬†
I‚Äôm just going to share what's worked, what hasn't, and what I‚Äôve leant along the way. 

If you're new here, welcome.
If you've been here a while, thanks for the engagement‚Ä¶

If you can't explain what your workforce technology actually does in under two minutes, it's probably not solving the right problems.

Here's how I explain Dayforce when someone asks:

We take the parts of frontline work that absolutely can‚Äôt fail, and put them in one place.

‚Üí Pay that's accurate the first time. Because chasing down payroll errors destroys morale faster than almost anything I‚Äôve seen in my whole career in this field.

‚Üí Schedules that respect both people and operations. Frontline teams need predictability so they can plan their lives. The business needs flexibility to respond to demand. You can't sacrifice one for the other - and most systems make you choose.

‚Üí Time tracking that doesn't require a detective. If your managers are spending half their week reconciling timesheets instead of leading people, something is fundamentally broken.

‚Üí Compliance that doesn't shatter every time a regulation changes. And regulations always change, especially across regions.

‚Üí Learning and mobility paths that actually strengthen your teams over time. Not tick-box training that nobody remembers three days later.

‚Üí Insights leaders can act on without stitching together twelve different reports from six different systems. If your workforce data lives in multiple places, you don't have data, you have a reconciliation problem.

This matters especially in organisations with large frontline workforces.

In a retail operation, a distribution centre, a hotel, a manufacturing plant‚Ä¶ one missed punch or one flawed schedule isn't a small issue. It cascades quickly into cost overruns, frustrated teams, or service failures.

When these fundamentals live in a single system, leaders can finally stop firefighting and start focusing on work that actually moves the business forward.

Most organisations think about HCM as an HR problem.

That's wrong, and it's expensive.

When you're evaluating or changing workforce systems, the conversation might start in HR. But the top line and bottom line impact spreads across every function that touches people, money, or operations.

1. HR needs fewer manual cycles and more time for strategic work. If your system creates noise instead of reducing it, they're stuck like heck in reconciliation instead of building culture or developing talent.

2. IT wants clean architecture they can actually support. When your HCM has a unified data model, the support burden drops dramatically. When it's six vendors stitched together with brittle integrations, they're firefighting constantly and nothing ever gets better.

3. Finance needs accuracy and predictability because labour is one of the most sensitive lines in any P&L. Small errors at the individual level compound fast when you're operating at scale across sites and shifts.

4. Operations needs reliability. A shift pattern that actually works. A team that shows up when they're supposed to. The ability to adjust quickly when demand changes or something breaks (because something always breaks).

5. If even one of these groups is struggling with your HCM system, the whole organisation feels it. Missed schedules cascade into service failures. Payroll errors destroy trust. Bad data leads to bad decisions.

So no, modern workforce technology isn't just an HR investment. It's a shared operational foundation for how work actually happens across your business. 

And if you want your business to prosper, you need to think ahead and realise that you can‚Äôt just keep one department happy - you need a system that works for all of them. 

Once you realise that, send me a message and let‚Äôs get you onboarded on Dayforce.

Your workforce system costs more than you think it does.

You can calculate the invoice cost. Software licenses, implementation fees, support contracts. That's the easy part.

The real cost is hidden in the operational friction nobody tracks or includes in budgets.

‚Üí Leaders spending the first two hours of their day validating reports before they trust them enough to use them. 

‚Üí HR teams building manual workarounds to patch gaps between systems that should talk to each other but don't. 

‚Üí Employees waiting hours or days for answers to simple questions. 

‚Üí IT maintaining integrations that break every time someone updates anything.

None of these moments looks dramatic on its own. Together, they drain time, morale, and operational efficiency in ways that never show up on a budget line, but absolutely show up in your results.

This is why unified workforce systems matter. Not because they're more convenient or easier to use, but because organisations genuinely function better when they aren't constantly stitching together the basics.

The companies I see moving fastest right now are the ones systematically removing layers of unnecessary complexity.

Fewer systems to check, fewer exceptions to manage, and fewer surprises landing at 4pm on a Friday when nobody has bandwidth left to deal with them.

We had a strong year at Dayforce EMEA.

The numbers matter, but what I'm most proud of isn't just the growth, it's how we got there:
